1093260172737347589.text: 13/n It's a biblical measure, kind of like asking everyone to return to their hometown for counting -- but this is AFAIK the only way to force a census and convince us all that there is not an infinite amount of Zcash lurking somewhere in the dark.

1093260171017629696.text: 12/n The only way I see that this can now be salvaged is to spoon a snapshot of all unshielded accounts on the Zcash chain onto a new Zcash chain at some predefined point in the future. For this, everyone would have to move their tokens into an unshielded account.

1093260169751003142.text: 11/n Remember the lengths the @ZerocoinProject went through for the ceremony? And now it's all for nothing. The person who found the exploit apparently doesn't even work for Zcash anymore. Go figure.

1093260168459157511.text: 10/n Zcash would have been frozen for a number of months. Is this a major inconvenience? For sure. But in my eyes it beats not ever being able to know that there may be an infinite amount of Zcash in a shielded account.

1093260166848540672.text: 9/n Once the patch for the vulnerability had been worked out, a hardfork containing such patch should have happened. Trading would resume at the moment of the snapshot, possibly months earlier.

1093260165472768001.text: 8/n After 24 hrs, the exact vulnerability should have been revealed. This invalidates everything that happens after to anyone who had any stake in the chain before and is honest (i.e. wouldn't use the exploit).

1093260164185100288.text: 7/n Exchanges would have been able to suspend trading within that time frame. Non-chain and cross-chain tx cannot be reverted, so this would have been important.

1093260162884927503.text: 6/n What should have happened is @ZerocoinProject should have notified the public that a critical vulnerability was discovered and trading should be suspended within 24 hrs, without disclosing the exact specs of the bug. Then, a snapshot would be taken.

1093260161165283329.text: 5/n *No-one can ever know now that the bug wasn't exploited.*

1093260159818874880.text: 4/n Zcash makes the case that it likely wasn't because they detected no trace.The people who were privy to the exploit are expert cryptographers probably would have know how to be discrete about this, hence this isn't much consolation to me (and shouldn't be to you either).

1093260158157946890.text: 3/n Now, in the ideal case a hand full of people knew of this bug for seven months. In a less ideal case, more people knew this for longer. We cannot know whether this bug was exploited.

1093260156476030976.text: 2/n The approach taken seriously downplays the severity of the bug. Users should be aware that this is an immature technology that should not be taken to be without dangers. There was a vulnerability that allowed unbounded minting of new tokens. It doesn't get much worse!

1093260154966106112.text: 1/n I don't agree with the general assessment that the Zcash vulnerability was handled well. The way that it was handled, i.e. business as usual while a small number of people worked in the background is exactly how it should *not* have been handled. And here is why:https://twitter.com/zooko/status/1092814766979145729 …

1090270555993866240.text: .@koeppelmann "Which information should be on chain will depend which shard it is on. Real estate prices are different between New York and Kansas, and this to an extent determines what can sensibly be built atop." Evolving web 3 infrastructure @ #AraCon2019pic.twitter.com/dVvcmTluRh
